questions.question_text: Which statements are correct concerning the leveraging of third-party data from the Snowflake Data Marketplace? (Choose two.)

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: AD
A. Data in the Snowflake Data Marketplace is already formatted and ready to query, and can be personalized for specific business needs.

D. Data from the Snowflake Data Marketplace is accessed through Snowflake's Secure Data Sharing technology, which allows users to access the data without copying or moving it to their own account.

B and C are incorrect statements. Loading data into a cloud provider as a consumer account is not required to leverage data from the Snowflake Data Marketplace, and the data can be accessed and used in a Snowflake account without restriction.

E is also an incorrect statement. Data transformations may not be required when combining Data Marketplace datasets with existing data in Snowflake, as it depends on the specific data being used and how it needs to be combined or analyzed.
A and D are correct

Selected Answer: AD
AD are correct

Why A
data is no where live in mkt place


it should be c

Selected Answer: AD
Correct

Selected Answer: AD
A and D are the correct answers. C could be confusing but you can actually move the data to your own account if you so wish.

Selected Answer: CD
https://docs.snowflake.com/en/user-guide/data-share-consumers
A and D

choices.A: Data is live, ready-to-query, and can be personalized.
choices.C: Data is not available for copying or moving to an individual Snowflake account.
choices.B: Data needs to be loaded into a cloud provider as a consumer account.
choices.E: Data transformations are required when combining Data Marketplace datasets with existing data in Snowflake.
choices.D: Data is available without copying or moving.

choices.B: How often the underlying base table is queried
choices.A: Whether or not it is also a secure view
choices.E: How often the materialized view is queried
choices.D: Whether the materialized view has a cluster key defined
choices.C: How often the base table changes

questions.question_text: What impacts the credit consumption of maintaining a materialized view? (Choose two.)

comments.content:
I agree with C & D.
https://docs.snowflake.com/en/user-guide/views-materialized.html#effects-of-changes-to-base-tables-on-materialized-views
Answer-c --> When a base table changes, all materialized views defined on the table are updated by a background service that uses compute resources provided by Snowflake.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: CD
More changes to base table increases credit consumption for materialized view maintenance
And. CE

Selected Answer: CD
CD are correct

https://docs.snowflake.com/en/user-guide/views-materialized#label-materialized-views-maintenance-billing
Answer CD as per the evidence in the link, user queries does not come under maintenance

C and E
Materialized views impact your costs for both storage and compute resources:

Storage: Each materialized view stores query results, which adds to the monthly storage usage for your account.

Compute resources: In order to prevent materialized views from becoming out-of-date, Snowflake performs automatic background maintenance of materialized views. When a base table changes, all materialized views defined on the table are updated by a background service that uses compute resources provided by Snowflake.

This one make more sense

comments.content:
I found this in Snowflake Doc :
Materialized Views and Clustering
Defining a clustering key on a materialized view is supported and can increase performance in many situations. However, it also adds costs.

https://docs.snowflake.com/en/user-guide/views-materialized#label-materialized-views-maintenance-billing

discussion.content:

This because al tables are clustered on Snowflake, there is no mention of re-clustering.

Selected Answer: CD
Agree with C and D:
https://docs.snowflake.com/en/user-guide/views-materialized#label-materialized-views-maintenance-billing

C and E
Materialized views impact your costs for both storage and compute resources:

Storage: Each materialized view stores query results, which adds to the monthly storage usage for your account.

Compute resources: In order to prevent materialized views from becoming out-of-date, Snowflake performs automatic background maintenance of materialized views. When a base table changes, all materialized views defined on the table are updated by a background service that uses compute resources provided by Snowflake.

I would rather go with the highly voted answers (C&D) and not the key provided (D&E) based on the Snowflake Guide: https://docs.snowflake.com/en/user-guide/views-materialized.html#effects-of-changes-to-base-tables-on-materialized-views

Selected Answer: CD
It is C and D for this.

Selected Answer: CD
clustering and base table modifications ratio

Selected Answer: CD
It's C&D
https://docs.snowflake.com/en/user-guide/views-materialized.html#label-materialized-views-maintenance-billing

Selected Answer: CD
In general, the costs are proportional to:

The number of materialized views created on each base table, and the amount of data that changes in each of those materialized views when the base table changes. Any changes to micro-partitions in the base table require eventual materialized view maintenance, whether those changes are due to reclustering or DML statements run on the base table.

The number of those materialized views that are clustered. Maintaining clustering (of either a table or a materialized view) adds costs.

https://docs.snowflake.com/en/user-guide/views-materialized.html#effects-of-changes-to-base-tables-on-materialized-views
